none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 31, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Curtis, July 31, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 20 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Agricultural and Mechanical College
--- OF TEXAS. ---

CORRESPONDENCE
ON MATTERS RELATING TO COLLEGE
PROPER SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO
THE CHAIRMAN.
WE INVITE CONSULTATION WITH
THE HEAD OF THIS DEPARTMENT, ON
ANY AND ALL TOPICS RELATING TO
AGRICULTURE AND HORTICULTURE.
WE MAKE A SPECIALTY OF FINE
STOCK.

Department Agriculture and Horticulture
GEO. W. CURTIS, B. S. A.

FACULTY.
CHAIRMAN :
H. H. DINWIDDIE.
TREASURER :
L. L. McINNIS.
J. R. COLE. R. WIPPRECHT.
W. L. BRINGHURST,
GEO. W. CURTIS,
R. H. WHITLOCK,
R. F. SMITH.

Chicago Ills.
College Station, Brazos Co., Texas, July 13" 1885

My Dear Prof. : Yours recd.
here - Wife brought it in with
her when she came in to
Chicago to wait for me —
Very many thanks for your
kindness - I want you to
write me at Anamosa Iowa
& give me the true inside
of some things - How did S-
secure an appointment by the
Board? Was glad to meet him
there but suspect there is
something back of it which I
do not know. Shall send
the Voucher & ck to Cole. as soon
as we get to Anamosa & will
then ck. for amt. due College
from me as pr your request
Josie tells me - by letter that
the calves are doing well & W-
wrote to same effect - Wish I
could see you & talk over some
things - Will see what can
be done about the house &
servants & write you more
anon. Had a splendid time
in Convention - Am one of the
executive Com. of C. for future work
Mrs C. joins with me in
Best of wishes to all especially
the Baby

Ever truly G W C [Curtis]

**Here's how I'm approaching this transcription:**

As a professional transcriptionist, my task is to accurately reproduce the text from this image, paying close attention to reading order, preserving errors, and interpreting the handwriting, while adhering to the specific HTML tags allowed. This letter, dated July 13, 1885, on Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas stationery, presents a challenge due to the cursive, somewhat scribbled purple ink handwriting. My process involves several steps.

First, I analyze the document's structure. The header includes the college name in a gothic font, and sub-text, with three distinct columns containing correspondence information, a departmental title, and faculty listings, respectively. The dateline presents a cross-out printed location and a handwritten location, and the letter includes a salutation, the body of the letter, and a signature.

Next, I'll transcribe the text, focusing on the order and interpreting the handwriting. I'll represent the layout as best as possible using permitted HTML tags. I'll identify and address ambiguous handwriting, like deciphering abbreviations or unclear letter forms, such as "S-" (which, after closer inspection, appears to be an "S"). The signature, which seems to be G. W. Curtis, is stylized and likely abbreviated as "G. W. C." and "G. W. Curtis".

While transcribing, I will use line breaks and paragraphs to approximate the original layout, given the HTML limitations. I'll pay close attention to any emphasis, representing it using the `<i>` tag, which is the best option given the allowed HTML set.  I will handle the strikethrough by transcribing the crossed-out text and noting in the context that it's struck through, since there is no available HTML tag for strikethrough from the prompt.

The final HTML will follow the correct structural order. I will pay careful attention to the dateline where the original "College Station, Brazos Co., Texas," is crossed out and replaced with the handwritten "Chicago Ills". The body's paragraphs are divided logically, and the signature will be transcribed accurately. I'll carefully review the transcript to ensure accuracy and adherence to the guidelines.

W
29 - Winona
Friday 30 -
Sat 1 -
Thu 6
Friday 7
Mo 10 Way
Thurs 13 -
Mon - 17 austin
[?] 24 austin
25 College -

**Transcription Analysis Summary** Okay, here's what I've got. The task is to take this image of handwritten notes and provide a text transcription, focusing on accuracy, interpreting ambiguous handwriting, and respecting the constraints given. First, I need to look at each line. It appears to be a schedule or list of some kind, likely related to dates and locations or activities. There’s a “W” at the top of the page, potentially a heading. Then, the rest is laid out as a list. The first line reads “W”. Could be a heading, could be Wednesday, but without more context it's just "W." The next entry is “29 - Winona.” The dash looks fine, and the city "Winona" is clearly written. Moving on, the next line is “Friday 30 -”. Here's the first tricky part. The number looks like a "0", a closed loop, but logically, if the preceding day is the 29th and this is a schedule, it might be the 31st if we're dealing with a 31-day month. I've scrutinized the writing, and I will be faithful to what I see and will write 30. There's a slight dot, but it's part of the pen stroke so it would be just "30". It looks like "30." and if the 0 has a dot, I will type "30.". The next line is “Sat 1 -”. This confirms the schedule order. The next lines are straight forward “Thu 6”, “Friday 7”. Moving on to the next line is "Mo. 10 Way" . The "Mo." is clear, and the 10 is clear, and "Way" is clear. It's written "Mo." and the dot is part of the writing. Next is “Thurs 13 -”. Again, straightforward and clear as "Thurs" or "Thus" and 13 is the number. Then, we have “Mon - 17 austin”. The 17 and "austin" appear clear. Then, there's a strikethrough/crossed-out line. The line is "k 24 austin". Now, this presents a problem. It looks like an "x" or scribble. Given the task requirements, I can't put a strikethrough tag, but I need to transcribe it as is, and that is "x 24 austin". The letter before 24 looks like a 'k'. I'll trust the shape of the stroke. The word "austin" is in the middle of a loop. The "austin" part is visible, even under the loop. The "k" or scribble is a mark that might mean deletion of the date, so I will write it as is: "k 24 austin". Finally, the last line is “25 College -”. This one is clear. Here's my final text transcription in `

` tags for each line break as instructed:

Friday 30 -
Sat 1 -
Thu 6
Friday 7
Mo. 10 Way
Thurs 13 -
Mon - 17 austin
k 24 austin
25 College -
